{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2968538,"name":"James Racadio","username":"Anadarko","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/65b543/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-09-17T20:23:45.536Z","cooked":"

We are converting our robot to Mecanum wheels. We have it all set up, and I used sample code I got from here. The code runs just fine, and our front left wheel turns, but that is it. We also get this error

20210917_1427433024×4032 4.7 MB

Any ideas? Our labview kid graduated last year.

If I had to guess, you all may be setting the front and rear motor controllers to the same channels.
Can you share a screenshot of your motor controller code where you all set each motor?

Did you start this code from a fresh project, or from an existing project?
Did you only modify Begin.vi and Teleop.vi?
I suggest you look in the other vi’s to see if a declaration of PWM 3 was made anywhere else that a programmer may have modified from the original default project.

The error message means that PWM 3 has been declared elsewhere in the project vis.

If it’s possible, could you create a zip of the directory Documents/LabVIEW Data/2020 Robot Project 3.0
It can be attached to a post for any one of us to sanity check it for you, or if you like you can email it directly to me to check.

P.S. as a quick check you can try changing the selected PWMs to 9,8,7,6 if they are unused on your robot. Change in code and where the PWM cables connect of course.

I switched PWM 3 to 4 and solved that issue. Now the code runs, but only the front left wheel turns. And then I get the following error.

20210921_0916023024×4032 4.54 MB

Ideas?

Strike that. I fixed that issue. Now, the error says
“The Loop that contains RobotDrive is not running fast enough. This error can occur if the loop contains too much code.”
How can I fix this? I am using the sample code given when I start a new project in Labview.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2021-09-21T14:32:22.401Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":50,"readers_count":49,"score":20.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396044,"topic_slug":"mecanum-wheels-coding","display_username":"James Racadio","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49479,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/mecanum-wheels-coding/396044/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2968772,"name":"mshafer1","username":"mshafer1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/96bed5/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-09-21T15:41:32.297Z","cooked":"

That basically means there’s too much code in teleop and it’s not finishing in the 20 ms that it’s expected to.

Take a look at it and see if there’s things that don’t need to update that fast (move them to periodic tasks), and if that’s not enough, you could try using this setup:

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2021-09-21T15:41:32.297Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":42,"readers_count":41,"score":18.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":396044,"topic_slug":"mecanum-wheels-coding","display_username":"mshafer1","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49479,"username":"Anadarko","name":"James Racadio","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/65b543/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24334,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/mecanum-wheels-coding/396044/8","custom_user_title":"Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2968778,"name":"James Racadio","username":"Anadarko","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/65b543/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-09-21T16:01:40.472Z","cooked":"

I didn’t get the setup you suggested.
Also, this is my Teleop. I don’t know what can be moved to periodic tasks or not. I am running 4 CIM motors for the wheels (one on each) could that be the issue?

20210921_1059023024×4032 4.61 MB

whoops - the link didn’t paste: Teleop | FRC LabVIEW Tutorials

Actually - for teleop that looks completely reasonable.

if there any code next to teleop.vi in the loop in main.vi?

If not (or that doesn’t solve it) - what does the driver station report for in the “charts” tab on the right? - if it’s really high, look in periodic tasks for any loops that don’t have a delay in them.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2021-09-21T16:55:15.545Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":32,"readers_count":31,"score":26.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":396044,"topic_slug":"mecanum-wheels-coding","display_username":"mshafer1","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.frclabviewtutorials.com/tutorials/teleop/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Teleop | FRC LabVIEW Tutorials","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24334,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/mecanum-wheels-coding/396044/10","custom_user_title":"Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2968788,"name":"Mark McLeod","username":"Mark_McLeod","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mark_mcleod/{size}/65145_2.png","created_at":"2021-09-21T17:19:21.182Z","cooked":"

He’s using the default robot project, so the message is probably just due to a transition.

Does this message occur repeatedly or just once or twice? Once is not an issue.

The message can occur once when transitioning between robot states, e.g., Enabled/Disabled, Autonomous/Teleop, as it’s just triggered as a result of the timing due to switching between robot states.

If the message happens repeatedly then it becomes something to look more closely at.

The message happens just once. However, I still have the issue of only the front left motor working. I am almost certain that the wiring is all correct (as it is wired exactly as the front left motor is.)

What are the lights on the Victor’s doing when you enable the robot? do they go solid orange? (this can help identify if they are receiving signals from the roborio. (http://www.ctr-electronics.com/downloads/pdf/Victor%20SPX%20User’s%20Guide.pdf)

Also - any other errors in the DS log?

During normal operation, blinking red means reverse throttle:

Both Blinking Red Reverse throttle is applied. Blink rate is
proportional to Duty Cycle

If you ONLY get red - check what your joystick is reading as you move it around in the driver station.
if you get some red, and some orange (dependent on joystic) - check power wiring from the pdb (including that a breaker is inserted)

Something more fundamental to double check.

On the Driver Station look at the “USB Devices” tab on the left.
Does the joystick you are trying to use show up as green in the “0” slot?
